questions.question: Let’s invite Bob and Sally.
questions.description: Here the verb invite is transitive because it has an object – Bob and Sally.

questions.question: You have baffled me.
questions.description: Here the verb baffled is transitive because it has an object – me.

questions.question: I usually sleep well.
questions.description: Here the verb sleep is intransitive because it does not have an object.

questions.question: Please come here.
questions.description: Here the verb come is intransitive because it does not have an object.

questions.question: Our team has won the championship.
questions.description: Here the verb has won is transitive because it has an object – the championship

questions.question: I bought her some flowers.
questions.description: Here the verb bought is transitive because it has objects. Actually, it has two objects – her and flowers

questions.question: Marriage changed him for the better.
questions.description: Here the verb changed is transitive because it has an object – him.

questions.question: Bob has changed a lot since he got married to Alice.
questions.description: Here the verb changed is intransitive because it does not have an object.

questions.question: We had to put off our visit to France.
questions.description: Here put off is transitive because it has an object – our visit

questions.question: You never cease to amaze me.
questions.description: Here amaze is transitive because it has an object – me.

questions.question: The car won’t start again this morning.
questions.description: Here start is intransitive because it does not have an object.

questions.question: She is doing well.
questions.description: Here is doing is intransitive because it does not have an object. Well is an adverb.
